message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound suggests atrial septal defect (ASD). Without treatment, ASD can lead to a reversal of left-to-right shunting, which can result in pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. All other options are not directly related to ASD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fixed splitting of the second heart sound suggests atrial septal defect. Without treatment, there is a risk of reversal of left-to-right shunting, leading to Eisenmenger syndrome. The other options are not related to atrial septal defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fixed splitting of the second heart sound indicates atrial septal defect (ASD). Without adequate treatment, long-standing ASD will lead to pulmonary hypertension, and eventually reversal of left-to-right shunting. Acute endocarditis is not specifically associated with ASD. Extra-cardiac left-to-right shunting is associated with patent ductus arteriosus, not ASD. Mitral stenosis is usually associated with a history of rheumatic fever, which is not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s fixed splitting of the second heart sound indicates atrial septal defect (ASD). Without adequate treatment, the left-to-right shunting caused by ASD may eventually reverse due to pulmonary vascular disease. This can lead to Eisenmenger’s syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition. Acute endocarditis is not directly related to ASD. Extra-cardiac left-to-right shunting is not a known complication of untreated ASD. Mitral stenosis is a potential complication of rheumatic heart disease, which the patient does not have a history of.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound suggests an atrial septal defect (ASD), which causes a left-to-right shunt. Without treatment, the patient may develop pulmonary hypertension and eventually develop right-to-left shunting. However, this is not a choice among the options presented, and therefore the correct answer is (D) Reversal of left-to-right shunting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fixed splitting of the second heart sound suggests atrial septal defect (ASD). Without adequate treatment, ASD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and eventually reverse of left-to-right shunting. Acute endocarditis and mitral stenosis are not typical complications of ASD. Extra-cardiac left-to-right shunting can occur in conditions such as patent ductus arteriosus, but it is not a complication of ASD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is a classic finding in an atrial septal defect (ASD). Without adequate treatment, there is a risk for developing pulmonary hypertension, which can lead to reversal of left-to-right shunting. Acute endocarditis, extra-cardiac left-to-right shunting, and mitral stenosis are not commonly associated with ASD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fixed splitting of the second heart sound suggests atrial septal defect (ASD), which causes left-to-right shunting. Without adequate treatment, ASD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and reversal of left-to-right shunting, which can cause cyanosis and right heart failure. Acute endocarditis and mitral stenosis are not common complications of ASD. Extra-cardiac left-to-right shunting is not associated with ASD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound indicates atrial septal defect (ASD), a congenital heart defect. Without adequate treatment, the defect can cause overload of the right ventricle and pulmonary vascular disease, leading to reversal of left-to-right shunting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of fixed splitting of S2 suggests a diagnosis of atrial septal defect (ASD). Without treatment, the patient is at risk of developing right ventricular hypertrophy, atrial fibrillation, and reversal of left-to-right shunting. Acute endocarditis is not associated with ASD. Extra-cardiac left-to-right shunting and mitral stenosis are not complications of ASD.
